item.title: By: Suhana
item.dc:creator: Suhana
item.description: Great piece of information. I'm an accidental DBA. Our logs were growing like crazy, 6MB database had 6GB log file size. I was trying to shrink the log file but it was not getting shrunk. The recovery model was FULL. The 'log_reuse_wait_desc' said 'LOG BACKUP'. I set up hourly transaction log backup and nightly full backup of the database. But still I was not able to shrink the file. I used SSMS and took a log back up, I didn't see the options quite closely. I accepted the defaults. But after reading your blog, I wanted to verify the options too - and the default for transaction log was "Truncate the transaction log". This is for SQL Server 2012. According to your article, you have stated no log file after the truncate only option can be used for point in time recovery. Does this change after the next nightly full backup?
item.content:encoded: Great piece of information. I’m an accidental DBA. Our logs were growing like crazy, 6MB database had 6GB log file size. I set up hourly transaction log backup and nightly full backup of the database. But still I was not able to shrink the file. I used SSMS and took a log back up, I didn’t see the options quite closely. I accepted the defaults. But after reading your blog, I wanted to verify the options too – and the default for transaction log was “Truncate the transaction log”. This is for SQL Server 2012. According to your article, you have stated no log file after the truncate only option can be used for point in time recovery. Does this change after the next nightly full backup?

item.title: By: Amanda
item.dc:creator: Amanda
item.description: Thank you for this article. I really enjoyed reading it. We recently have been having problems with our transaction logs growing to big for our resources and I was toying with the idea of truncating but I am glad I read your article first...not really sure what to do yet though. I am trying to limit the stress on the database server as it has a lot of things hitting it already (code, customers using our software, and of course people directly accessing it).
